kernel-modules/intel-i40e/centos/build_s.message:
Off topic: Not something that needs to be addressed, but rather a question for learning purposes:

I was wondering what the proper criteria for choosing the base commit identifiers are.

I see that the chosen commit IDs are the last updates for kernel-std, kernel-rt and the drivers that belong to each build_srpm.data file. If this is the way to go, I will attempt to replicate this approach with my changes as well, assuming that I will get to update a driver in the future.

The reference document mentions what the variables do, but not how they ought to be used. (i.e., https://docs.starlingx.io/developer_resources/packaging_ref.html )

This usage makes sense according to the description. One would be safe to assume that the latest commit ID (referenced here) would have been used so no patching conflicts. If you were to add a new patch and this driver built fine, then these SRCREVs would not need to be touched. If you do get a patch conflict in the driver, you would rebase and update this value. So yes, you should replicate this in driver updates. One could argue that you could work out the last commit ID which would not result in patch conflicts, but I don't see much value in that. Draw the line in the sand with what is current and move forward from there.

Yes, that's the way to go.  I confirmed with Scott.  If you follow this and build with changes uncommitted, it appears you get an initial tis version of 1.  Once you commit, the tis number will show 2.  I would've preferred 0 and 1 instead of 1 and 2, but it is what it is....

similar comment as the other reviews.  May be best for Dan or Chuck to comment, if we need $ROOT as part of these exports

The reference to $ROOT for the purposes of dh_install is optional. 

According to https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/dh_install.1.html: "From debhelper compatibility level 7 on, dh_install will fall back to looking in debian/tmp for files, if it does not find them in the current directory (or wherever you've told it to look using --sourcedir)."

nova/virt/libvirt/imagebackend.py.message:
I wonder why was it calling the disk.extend() to begin with, though.

I see that extend() in turn calls `qemu-img resize`:

    processutils.execute('qemu-img', 'resize', image.path, size)

Okay, so previously we were doing:

  qemu-img create -f qcow2 backing_file=foo backing_fmt=bar PATH  # libvirt_utils.create_cow_image
  qemu-img resize PATH SIZE  # from disk_extend

and now we're doing:

  qemu-img create -f qcow2 backing_file=foo backing_fmt=bar size=SIZE PATH

Makes sense to me.

hi, this is where the requirements change is described for stable maintenance:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/dependency-management.html#stable-branch-maintenance

It says: "Raising effective minimums is only acceptable during Phase I, and only due to security issues."
This is a bit old description, haven't been changed when the phases were changed during the Extended Maintenance process introduction ("Phase I" meant "Maintained" so within 6 month after the release).

For upper constraints it says: "In stable branches, we usually only update constraints for projects managed within the OpenStack community. Exceptions are made for other projects when there are gate issues."

So in this respect, I would say what we usually say: best is to avoid dependency (minimum constraints in this case) changes, though, if the team is confident enough that it won't cause breakage for end users / vendors (for example all the supported distros have higher version of the given package that the actual lower constraints contains), then there can be exceptions in my understanding.

In this particular case we are talking about an openstack managed package (oslo.utils), on the other hand it does not solve a gate issue. So in short: there can be exceptions, but it must be considered, and best is to avoid (to keep stable branches really stable).

stable/xena u-c for oslo.utils is 4.10.0[1], so i think requirements.txt update should be fine in this case.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/4e8983fc1ad9d96202791ec7ab93128191061926/upper-constraints.txt#L580

Thanks Elod for all the details.

Wrt Raising minimum version it seems it's talking only about global requirements[1] not project specific minimum requirements. Can you please cross check if it's same policy for updating requirements.txt in projects and global-requirements.txt in openstack/requirements? Shouldn't be same as global-requirement is more generic/shared across all OpenStack projects, every project requirements.txt should just not conflict with global-requirements.txt.

Also reading again[2] mentions to bump minimum in requirements.txt after updating upper-constraints.txt in openstack/requirements if it's not already contains required version. This makes sense as without it updates will not work as most jobs use upper-constraints. This doesn't specify anything related to stable but again [3] mentions that for OpenStack libraries updates are allowed in u-c for stable releases. Exception needed only for non-openstack libraries.

Yeap i got the idea of avoiding bumps in stable to keep the projects stable, but just not clear about the policies across projects. As i see nova/cinder already have bumped oslo.utils same as the proposed here in both wallaby and xena. So wrt availability of required versions for end users/vendors it seems those already have required version of oslo-utils to support wallaby/xena nova and cinder and may be some other projects as well.

I can modify this patch without updating oslo.utils minimum version but wanted to take this opportunity to clarify the raised issue on the policy here.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/stable/xena/global-requirements.txt#L165
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/dependency-management.html#updating-the-minimum-version-of-a-dependency
[3] https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/dependency-management.html#upper-constraints

global-requirements.txt does not contain lower constraints in general (only at python version differentiation), which means, when the doc talks about minimums, then it must be about project specific requirements.txt, in my understanding.

"Raising effective minimums is only acceptable during Phase I, and only due to security issues."

As i see nova/cinder already have bumped oslo.utils same as the proposed here in both wallaby and xena. So wrt availability of required versions for end users/vendors it seems those already have required version of oslo-utils to support wallaby/xena nova and cinder and may be some other projects as well.

Both nova and cinder modified oslo.utils minimum version for their rc1/rc2, so the change were part of their original final Wallaby release.

Anyway, I can agree that part, that nova and cinder have oslo.utils 4.8.0 as their minimum requirements in stable/wallaby, so it might not hurt end users if we bump it in neutron as well, but correct me if i'm wrong. Also in this sense, distros probably have at least 4.8.0 due to they need that anyway for nova and cinder, which means it's probably less problematic from distros perspective as well.

(Nevertheless, if anyone is aware of such cases where merging this patch would break things then this fix should not be backported)

Hope this all make some sense and helps a bit.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

specs/approved/power-control-intermediar.message: So... db table for this to be tracked?

So you're right here in pointing out that this would require a new database table if implemented as described, and this slipped my mind when I was drafting this spec. Additional database entries, the cycles required to make those queries, and the overhead required to manage such a database was something I wanted to avoid, and after thinking this through I *think* I have a solid plan:

What will remain here is the implementation detail of authenticating Sessions via application credential ID/secret. This is for two reasons: the first being that I want to avoid handling credentials (specifically passwords) directly wherever possible, and the second being that because one can authenticate a request with only the app. credential id and that identifier's secret, we avoid requiring a custom schema to provide details such as project id and user/project domain.

However, instead of having my SessionService code generate and manage these Session objects, I instead plan to request a scoped authorization token for the user, project, and domain associated with the application credential and return that to the user as the X-Auth-Token in the header.

As for the identifier for this pseudo-Session (which would essentially just be a Keystone auth token), I'm not 100% certain which direction to go, but after some research I feel that perhaps the token's audit ID could be appropriate? The Identity API reference notes that "You can use these audit IDs to track the use of a token ... without exposing the token ID to non-privileged users." so my takeaway was that this could work for this purpose, although do let me know if this would be an inappropriate use. (ref: https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html)

Finally, this would also address the problem of Session expiration. In the implementation described here, it would have to be managed by new code that I would have to write, but in having the Sessions interface be a proxy for the Identity service, these sessions would be automatically expired by an already existing service.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I will likely not follow up on this review; but I'm putting a -1 for visibility. Please merge it over my objections without re-review if the concerns are invalid.

This is an API-breaking change. pip-and-virtualenv expose environment variables that can -- and are -- used by deployers to set custom pip configurations. That concern isn't a reason to not do this -- but it is a reason to make sure it's loudly evangelized before pushing the change.

Additionally, the dib-python module itself says it is deprecated: https://docs.openstack.org/diskimage-builder/latest/elements/dib-python/README.html and we should use /usr/bin/python3 directly. If we're going to break deployers; lets do it exactly once. I also suggest talking to Ironic deployers and seeing how difficult it'd be to replicate the functionality provided by pip-and-virtualenv environment variables.
This will likely need some followup to keep centos7-python2 working

We use this at Yahoo. This might be another con for us trying to use master branch. Sigh. Please leave it, or propose a replacement and give me time (MOAR TIME) to do the replacement. Otherwise, this will break us. Unless I pin to an older version. Sigh. Not sure this means a -1 since it is my opinion, but whatever 😂

Without knowing what your builds do, I would expect the only changes you need to do is:
- just use python3, no need to use $DIB_PYTHON
- replace any uses of "virtualenv" with "python3 -m venv"

Thats it. Or you could add the pip-and-virtualenv element to your own element dependencies, but its only going to get more bitrotten at this point so YMMV

ironic/api/controllers/v1/node.py.message: Don't we need to pass the fields in here too, so the .next also has the fields= query added?
We do. See L1401. (Let me know if I should add some comment or something to make it more obvious...)

ah whoops missed that, sooo thats why you've renamed the fields parameter for this function! not sure I'm a massive fan of passing two kwargs into the function essentially representing the exactly same data.

man this code is a mess relying on **kwargs :( 

personally I think I'd prefer to remove fields_in_response from this function and replace it with kwargs.get('fields') which will make it more obvious that its getting passed through.

well, we can't do that easily. Because the 'fields' query parameter value is not necessarily equal to the 'fields' in the response. See L1541 :-( It would be wrong to tack on those fields in the query part of the URL if the user didn't actually specify them.

Which doesn't mean that we can't do what you want, by eg moving down the 'fields in the response' logic to here, but I don't actually think that makes sense, and I don't really want to touch that much of the code.

I think it is good to have the distinction between the fields in the response and the fields in the url's query part.

I could put in a comment about that somewhere if you have a suggestion...

man I hate this code sometimes... perhaps something like:

  if fields == _DEFAULT_RETURN_FIELDS:
     kwargs.pop('fields')

to avoid needing to pass around if the fields were specified or not.

I also just realised I think we're missing including the fields= query in the individual links for the nodes in the collection (if we want it to do that) and if we were to do that then we'd need logic similar to above in the _convert_with_links function anyway.

My suggestion is:

 def convert_with_links(nodes, limit, url=None, **kwargs):
    collection = NodeCollection()
    collection.nodes = [
        Node.convert_with_links(n, fields=kwargs.get('fields'))
        for n in nodes]
    marker_uuid = None
    if nodes:
        # The UUID of the last node in the list, needed for generating
        # the 'next' link. (This is to handle the case where the response
        # doesn't include the UUIDs so the info is not available in
        # collection.nodes.)
        marker_uuid = nodes[-1].uuid
    if kwargs.get('fields') == _DEFAULT_RETURN_FIELDS:
        # Fields are the default set, so there is no need to
        # include it in the URL
        kwargs.pop('fields')
    collection.next = collection.get_next(limit, url=url,
                                          marker=marker_uuid, **kwargs)

could even do:

 def convert_with_links(nodes, limit, url=None, fields=None, **kwargs):
     ...
     if fields != _DEFAULT_RETURN_FIELDS:
         kwargs['fields'] = fields

although I think the first option is clearer.

Also perhaps instead of setting fields to the default set of fields in the API function below we should move that logic into the convert with links function above, so its like:

def _convert_with_links(..., fields=None):
  if fields is None:
      fields = _DEFAULT_RETURN_FIELDS

I don't care about passing around if the fields were specified or not. I do care that the code is written so that it is clearer/easy to understand, so that it can be maintained, etc. I'm not convinced that your suggestion will make it easier; it seems like it'll make it harder. (Actually, I'm not quite sure I understand your suggestion.)

I don't like this code either, but I also don't have time to try to clean it up. Which is perhaps how we got to this point :-(

For me, since I worked on it, the code seems clean, separating the fields in the response from the fields in the url's query, since they are not necessarily the same. And keeping the query-fields in kwargs along with any other query-fields is consistent too.

I'm not sure it is broken for an individual node. If it is, that is a separate patch. I think there is too much going on here, to also address that. (I just skimmed that code, ugh, I think it might be ok, but I'll verify/test later...)

cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/powermax/.message: This code is very confusing as you use a Log.warning() in the first case but then you create a separate 'msg' variable and log that for the other cases.  I think this should be changed to be consistent please.
Thanks Jay. This method returns a msg string which is why the msg is a variable.  When it is warning, None is returned.

Do you need this check? If initiator_group is None, you will have taken the branch at line 666 and won't execute the 'else' block containing this statement.  And actually, now that I think about it, if initiator_group is None, you will already have raised an AttributeError at when you call initiator_group.get() at line 674, so you will never hit this code.

I find this message a bit confusing.  I think the warning is that the initiator names are missing from the login table; the rest of the message is saying that you have decided that you have found the correct initiator group anyway ... and are going to use it?  (I think not saying the last part in your message is what's confusing.)

Also, I guess this is a warning because even though it's a recoverable error, it could be a sign that there's something weird going on in the backend?
Not at all Brian.  As always, I appreciate the feedback

Thanks for the explanation, Helen.

I wonder if this should be a debug-level log instead of a warning?  It sounds like everything is OK, so there's nothing for the operator to worry about.  Unless a bunch of these happening could be a sign that the array's health is not good, so you want operators to be aware that it's happening.

And, sorry to bikeshed this, but instead of saying "therefore there is no reason ign cannot be reused", maybe be more affirmative and say "therefore reusing ign"

The comment on this review goes into more detail. This warning summarizes, but based on your comment it is not clear enough.

You are correct this is recoverable error.  An initiator group (aka host) in powermax can be created but unless it becomes part of a masking view and scanned(FC) logged in (iSCSI) an entry will not be created in the login table.  
Therefore, if for whatever reason a successful scan/login does not succeed and the cleanup does not successfully delete the initiator group, the initiator group remains and most likely, will have the correct initiators (from the openstack supplied connector object).  Therefore there is no reason why it cannot be reused on a subsequent attach operation.

Do you think something like the following is clearer

LOG.warning(
    "Found initiator group %(ign)s, but could not "
     "find initiators %(ins)s in the login "
     "table. The contained initiator(s) are the "
     "same as those supplied by OpenStack, therefore "
     "there is no reason %(ign)s cannot be reused.",
     {'ign': init_group_name,
      'ins': initiator_names,
      'ign': init_group_name})

don't need this one ... this is still a two-element dict since the first and third key are the same (so removing it won't hurt, because you are already passing a two-element dict to the log function, and the coverage report shows that line 677 is being executed)

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Sorry for my ignorance, but is it possible to update the fdb table directly leveraging the l2pop mechanism instead of broadcasting the packet?
Yes in fact that is what I am doing it right now.

This may require that we allow the router IP to get into the br-tun flow and then probably drop it at the FLOOD_TO_TUN.
Also we should allow the DVR MAC as 'dst' to enter the patch-int from br-tun. ( This has to happen after we replace the DVR host MAC by the Gateway MAC. This flow mod has to happen in the br-tun flows before the packet hits the patch-int)
Enough complexity by itself, not sure if this would cause any other MAC table pollution in the br-int.
Any thougths?

What if no such packet send out from compute instance? Seems we are trying to fix the problem based on the "problem" itself. The bug [1] is a scenario testing, no garp, we will not fix that. Right?

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1859638

I understand the concept and the goal of this patch because I helped (briefly) on the development. I would like anyone else to check if this description is enough to understand what is being implemented.

I'm saying that because the concept could be, the first time you see this patch, difficult to understand.

Any feedback to improve the commit message, if needed, is welcome.
+1 for that 😊

what if keepalived VIP is not used with those allowed address pairs? There are other use cases where several ports would have same allowed address pair. What will those active/inactive states say to users then?

I mean maybe we don't even want to expose this info to users.

In such case, if there will be different IPs configured as allowed_address pair for different ports, all of them will be "active" by default.
But of course, I'm fine with hiding it from users. I just though that it could be good if user will have additional info which port is actually configured as the active one, that may help debugging issues probably.

ok, I see now. But TBH even if such vip will be marked as "inactive" it will work fine on the instance level. "Active/Inactive" is effectively only used by neutron-server to populate arp entry to the L3 agents with dvr routers.
Maybe we should introduce also server side config option to "use_allowed_address_pairs_as_vip" and expose this "active" attribute through API only if that config option is enabled? Wdyt?
As this field makes sense really only for dvr routers, I disable it when enable_dvr=False thus I don't need to introduce yet another config knob for that. Will work for You?
I think this makes sense if we really want to expose this info to users. However I don't think this is strictly needed for this patch. Anyway I'm ok with both options

> In such case, if there will be different IPs configured as allowed_address pair for different ports, all of them will be "active" by default

Well, I meant the case of same IP as allowed address pair but without a VIP floating between them, active/inactive has no sense in this case, has it?

> But of course, I'm fine with hiding it from users. I just though that it could be good if user will have additional info which port is actually configured as the active one, that may help debugging issues probably.

IMO this field makes sense only for VRRP based VIP use case, no matter if router is DVR or not. My vision is that this case is buggy with DVR routers and current patch fixes that issue, and this fix should work fine even without exposing 'active' state through API.
But what is the sense to have same IP address configured in 2 vms (added to 2 ports) in same network and use them both together? Is there use case for that?
BGP Anycast based load balancing and alike, where AAP is required to at least pass ARP spoofing protection and security groups.

Let me briefly describe my vision.
Allowed address pair feature lets ports to have additional IP(+MAC)s that will be allowed by security groups and MAC/ARP spoofing filters. By design it's kind of "passive" and does not imply to control actual IP assignment inside VM. 
Actual IP assignment is controlled by external processes, like keepalived and this is where active/passive state should be stored. By adding "active" to the allowed address pair we kind of mixing these two. Moreover allowed address pairs may be used not only for VIP scenario, but for traffic monitoring or like that. This does not depend on whether router is DVR or not.
I'd split this patch into two: 1st fixes the issue, 2nd adds API attribute and extension: easier to review and discuss. What do you think?

I was thinking about it a bit more and IMHO that API change is kind of part of the bug fix. It's not necessary to make datapath working really but for users to see which port is "active" now and where such IP is/should be actually really running is good and may be very helpful for debugging eventual connectivity issues in such cases.

It's also good for API tests https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/+/795358 to see if adding/modifying allowed address pairs on ports works as expected in Neutron.

So if that's not "hard" requirement from You I would like to see what others things about it and maybe keep all in that one patch.

TBH I'm not sure how often AAPs are used for purposes not involving actual AAP address assignment inside VM. My concern is that if there are still such cases - new API attribute will be misleading and making API unclear. If there are no such use cases - we should be fine. Anyway the bug could be fixed without exposing 'active' in the API
Yes, thanks (as API change is not related to the bug fix and could be reviewed and agreed separately)

I understand Your point and I know that better way could be to introduce some new attribute to port, instead of using allowed_address_pair as VIP address. But the reality is that people are using it like that since long time - see e.g. OpenShift clusters on OpenStack.
Do You think we should introduce one additional config option to enable adding that attribute to the allowed_address_pairs? Or maybe should we do some logic like:

    if agents_with_monitor_allowed_address_pair_garp != 0:
        add_active_field_to_allowed_address_pairs()

so it would be controlled by the agent's config option really. Wdyt?
So what You are proposing is to keep that "active" field hidden in this patch and add one more to add this value in the api, is that correct?

Maybe it could be a bit confusing, but from the other hand, in cases which this patch is trying to address having that knowledge on which port AAP is actually "active", so which mac address is populated in the qrouter namespace may be useful for debugging some connectivity issues.
If You are really strongly against exposing that using API, I can change that patch to hide it from there, but IMO it could be good if we expose it there and document what it means.

What would that mean? If we decide to stay with this new property I'd mark it "active" only when it actually becomes active (after sending/catching gARP request). Initially all are passive, aren't they?

Actually no - initially when allowed_address pair is added to one port it is "active" on that port as this port is expected to be really using that IP.
When same IP is added to more than one port in same network, we will need to wait for garp to determine where it is really active so initial assumption is that first port to which it was added had this IP.

Actually it means that MAC-IP address pair is propagated to the DVR router's namespaces so it is possible to access that IP using the DVR router.
I updated that text a bit. I hope it will be better for You now.
So a user added an AAP to the VM and see it 'active' - her/his expectation would be that this new IP is accessible while it's actually not. That is confusing.

I think the issue you're seeing is due to the fact that you're setting out_port to a value that corresponds to a table, not a valid egress port [1].

One approach is to identify the correct egress port and have it egress there. The actual openflow port number of non-reserved ports will change every time the bridge is re-built, which can happen when OVS restarts. It's not a constant we can hard-code.

Another approach is to specify OFPP_TABLE as the out_port. This is a reserved port that causes a packet-out to be re-evaulated by the pipeline (all the way back to table 1). This of course means that we need to be sure our rules are written in a way such that the packet doesn't get in to a loop where it is kicked to the controller, re-submitted, then kicked back to the controller over and over.

There may be another approach someone else has. This is what comes to mind at the moment, I'll spend a little more time thinking about this.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6918f4a2372991a41d02fa2313b38de157ac5ab3/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/common/constants.py#L93

Why this change?

we need to first try to match in table 21 for specific IP addresses (e.g. fixed_ips) and if there will be no match then go to rule which will send packets to table 26 or 27 (GARP_SNOOP_TABLE) to send it to controller.
Without this change all packets are first going to controller through table 26 or 27 and connectity is broken

Restart ovs-agent will cause all these learnt flows be cleaned by the agent stale flow clean process due to the cookie change. I don't think the GARP will be sent out again when you restart the agent. So actually this patch IMO should be just aimed for a long standing cloud: the user just created VM once, and no cloud deployment changing/upgrading at all. In such situation we may say they will not touch the agent. But from my experiences, cloud users can upgrade their cloud, change the config options, migration the hosts/vms and so on. Each action can cause agent restart, flow re-install etc. So if we do not handle these cases, this patch can be considered that is just for a very very corner case. But if we handle these situations, IMO, this patch may look a bit too heavy to achive the original purpose.

This packet will finally go out the original host and flood to all tunnels, and finnally hit packet-in (to controller) to all ovs-agents, a thundering herd. This can become a attact point. This is what we intend to? The following is the flow pipeline:
  table=0,    priority=1,arp,in_port=CONTROLLER,dl_dst=ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff actions=resubmit(,22)
  table=22,    priority=1,dl_vlan=1 actions=strip_vlan,load:0x44->NXM_NX_TUN_ID[],output:8,output:6,output:7

Firstly, assuming you have two hosts A and B. VM in A sent a GARP out, hit this "packet-in" function, and then this line send GARP out. B receive the GARP, and in the end, the GARP still hit the "packet-out".
Secondly, this will cause broadcast storm after all controllers (ovs-agents) install the flow. Assume you have N ovs-agent, the original GARP will be enlarge N times.
Thirdly, this packet out here will hit each ovs-agent packet-in (this function Line 280) N times, especially for the flow existing check in line 308.
Finally, these behaviors are not friendly to large scale deployment technically, IMO.

tools/ovn_migration/tripleo_environment/.message: I find this a bit confusing because the host are actually compute nodes. One can be mislead and think it's controller nodes.
I can rename this as ovn-controllers (that is actually the inventory group name used)
Right, this is the location used by the containers to read the config. That will be even faster.

Probably it could be done faster if You would run it just on one controller node and check in db with query like:

    select * from agents where configurations LIKE '%\"interface_driver\": \"iptables_hybrid\"%'

if it will return any agent. But from the other hand, migration is not something what is done often so waiting few minutes more for that check shouldn't be big deal.
I tested with 100 computes in the inventory (simulated with the existing 2 ones) it took 16 seconds. With 1000 computes it was about 4 minutes (with default forks set to 50).

I know I'm the one who recommended doing it via ansible. I like the SQL approach too - but it's a bit fragile. I did something similar in the past: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/791451/1/tools/ovn_migration/tripleo_environment/playbooks/roles/prepare-controllers/tasks/main.yml and was not happy with it because it relied on crudini and also is not readable and thus error prone.

That said, I think what Roman provided is quite a good result and can be even improved by increasing the fork. I think 4 minutes on 1k environment is a good number.

Actually "interface_driver" is the driver type, in both cases "openvswitch".

I should look for:
  "ovs_hybrid_plug": true

To be honest, I would rely on reading the configuration parameter.

To access to the DB I need (1) to identify and access to a controller, (2) find the DB container (in HA they have different names) and (3) execute a multiple command query inside the mysql CLI. Reading the config param is easier.

I like this approach actually, for a huge number of nodes it can be slow. I'm removing the +W to see what Jakub/Terry/others. Also not sure if we can/should assume that the tool will have access to the SQL database
Roman, thanks for your time testing this patch and providing this info.

perhaps we should include that pound sign is not on the line to avoid positive match on:

 firewall_driver = openvswitch
Right, I'll use lookup('ini') to simplify this search. It is more robust.

I don't know if it is really possible with Ansible or not but maybe we can improve that by failing on the first agent which will have iptables_hybrid driver. There is no need to check all of them in such case probably.
But it don't need to be done now. 4 minutes measured by Roman in IMO ok during the migration task.

Agreed 😊

-1 just for starting the discussion

Okay, we have some insight, that this might be a problem with apiserver constraints or some stale data reply from HA apiservers. In any case we need a fix to prevent such a failure and a guarantee that we're able to recover.

I would think that once we can recover from this once we periodically fetch a full list of resources in the watcher (we called it "reconciliation" back when it was implemented), but I'd like a second opinion on that.

I'd only want a warning logged when we hit this and I'm happy with the patch. Something like "Pod <ns>/<name> has no .spec.nodeName set. This is unexpected as it's supposed to be scheduled. Ignoring".

There's no guarantee how a thread will get scheduled on the CPU between we fetch the resource list and we actually add a resource state to the queue. Imagine this:

1. Queue for resource foo has 2 events A and B, A is waiting in ResourceNotReady, so it's stuck for a longer while.
2. Reconciliation thread gets a list of resources and starts injecting them, but not yet gets to the resource foo.
3. Resource foo changes and watcher gets event C and adds it to the queue.
4. Our reconciliation loop gets to the resource foo and injects outdated state that reflects event B, not C.
5. Thanks to [1] events B and C are ignored and we only take the injected event which basically makes us ignore changes in C.

We could work this around by making sure the queues are priority queues based on resourceVersion. The problem is that K8s docs state that resourceVersion is purely an implementation detail and you shouldn't rely on it's content. With etcd it's actually always going up, so that would work, but again, they deliberately warn against it.

[1] https://github.com/openshift/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kuryr_kubernetes/handlers/asynchronous.py#L100-L104

Yes, from my understanding the event would be ignored[1] and then retried by reconciliation.
On the reconciliation topic, Even though it's mentioned in the comment here[2] I can't fully get why we avoid adding the event to the queue as the injected would be latest version, I think.
[1] https://github.com/openshift/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/kuryrport.py#L268-L272
[2] https://github.com/openshift/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kuryr_kubernetes/handlers/asynchronous.py#L60-L61

and we fetch the Pod again before requesting the VIF so it's supposed to be the current version of the resource.

https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/kuryrport.py#L226-L229

According to [1] pods cannot be rescheduled. This has to be a bit different case here.

oslo_limit/limit.py.message:
The only remotely possible issue I could think of with this is if a caller wanted to be able to distinguish between a limit that is not found vs a limit that has been set deliberately to zero. But, enforce_limits does not tolerate a "limit" of None presently, so to do that it would have to be changed to treat limit=None as another over limit condition.

I don't think I could predict whether any callers would want to be able to distinguish between not found and zero, though. For my current use case, I am fine with only zero.

Just wanted to mention the potential use case if anyone else thinks that might be important to oslo.limit users.
The `None` capabilitie could be added later as an improvement if the need arises in use. For now the current version of these changes LGTM.

Yep, and I started thinking I would return {'limit': None} in the dict. But then I got to thinking that the enforce doesn't tell you whether or not the limit was zero or unregistered, and plumbing None through the results as well would be more work. This way, all the tests that validate the unregistered limit still show the same behavior, which is nice validation that this doesn't break anyone who currently relies on it.

TypeError happens when val isn't a dict.
For example, klist=['foo','bar'] and odict['foo'] is an integer.

In the case of "neq" and "nin", if there is even one key different from the one specified by filter, it will be True.
For example, if the key of "vimConnectionInfo" is "vim1" and "vim2", it is not excluded by the filter="(neq,vimConnectionInfo/@key,vim1)".
Is this the intended specification?

The spec for AttributeFilter is only concisely written in SOL013 5.2.2.
The spec doesn't say much when the dict in question has more than one key.

As the spec isn't very clear, I think it is better to be permissive and return maybe extra results.

ansible/module_utils/kolla_container_wor.message: So we're going with the docker data structure, and forcing podman to produce the same?
Yes, the objective was to change original docker functionality as little as possible.
Not sure if this makes sense in systemd land.

There are 2 approaches possible with running container with systemd:
1. creating container with systemd - problem with this is that after machine reboot or service restart it recreates container
2. creating container with docker/podman in state "created" and then starting it with systemd service, which is approach we think is better, more logical and works in the same way as it is now with docker
Same goes for destroying containers

I wrote a playbook to check:
  ---
  - name: Check cloud-init facts 
    hosts: controller-0
    tasks:
      - name: Show cloud-init cfg
        shell: |
          cat /etc/cloud/cloud.cfg.d/99-tripleo*
        register: command_out
      - name: Print cloud.cfg.d
        debug:
          msg: "{{ command_out.stdout }}"
      - name: Reboot node
        become: true
        reboot:
      - name: Check cloud-init status
        shell: systemctl is-active cloud-init.service || systemctl is-enabled cloud-init.service
        failed_when: false
        become: true
        register: cloud_init_enabled
      - name: Wait for cloud-init to finish, if enabled
        community.general.cloud_init_data_facts:
          filter: status
        register: res
        until: >
          res.cloud_init_data_facts.status.v1.stage is defined and
          not res.cloud_init_data_facts.status.v1.stage
        retries: 50
        delay: 5
        when:
          - cloud_init_enabled.rc is defined
          - cloud_init_enabled.rc == 0
      - name: Print loud_init_data_facts
        debug:
          msg: "{{ res.cloud_init_data_facts }}"

I will review it and test it again today, but I -1 it just because we need to land first:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/validations-libs/+/823515

Because I want to tag 1.5.1 with this patch first.
Jiri, won't it be possible to break it up in small patches in order to make the regression testing easier?

I don't believe that splitting into multiple patches would be likely to help with testing. 

Patch touches the core functionality of the framework, validation retrieval, results processing etc, but it does so in a functionally equivalent way. API signatures are preserved, you can still supply the args as before, but you will get a deprecation warning.

If I were to split it into multiple patches, the regression tests would have to be performed the same way for each. No time would be saved, and chance for something to slip would actually grow, because every time you would have to test the same things over and over again.

In any case...

Unit tests and functional tests (those cover most common CLI uses) would make any sort of deficiency very obvious. Because every time you write 'validator *' you hit the changed code.[1]
